abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Privatization Adjustment
            Loan and Privatization Technical Assistance Loan Project for
            Peru were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, project
            suitability was likely, Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: it is easy to underestimate the costs and
            time needed for such complex transactions. This mistake was
            committed by the Bank and the Peruvians, as both the cost
            and the time required for the program have been more than
            double the appraisal estimates. Top-level political support
            is critical for success. When the message from the top was
            clearly in favor of privatization, the process moved ahead
            rapidly. Now that there appears to be more ambivalence,
            progress is much slower. It is more efficient to have one
            technical assistance operation that covers all
            privatizations rather than several sector-specific technical
            assistance operations. Sector policy and regulatory reform
            should be well underway before privatization in the sector,
            so that bidders can feel that they are entering a secure
            environment, and will have a sound basis for calculating
            their bids. Much of Peru's success in privatization is
            due to the progress that was made beforehand in preparing
            comprehensive sectoral legislation and rules.
